forecast.status_quo_outcome: Yes. The Harmonized Tariff Schedule would continue to list the 50% tariff for Lesotho due to long-standing bureaucratic inertia.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: The U.S. Trade Representative or another relevant body pushes through a technical correction to the Harmonized Tariff Schedule as part of a miscellaneous clean-up package, and this correction is implemented before June 1, 2025, removing the erroneous tariff listing for Lesotho.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: The bureaucratic inertia that has kept this tariff anomaly in place for decades continues for another five weeks. Given the tariff has no real-world economic impact, there is no impetus for officials to prioritize its correction, and the Harmonized Tariff Schedule remains unchanged on the resolution date.
forecast.rationale: My forecast is based primarily on the overwhelming force of bureaucratic inertia, especially concerning issues with no tangible economic or political impact. The provided 2018 AP article indicates that this 50% tariff on certain furskins from Lesotho is an error that has existed since the 1980s. The fact that it has persisted through multiple presidential administrations suggests that the mechanisms for correcting such an obscure error are slow and require a level of attention that this issue does not command. The tariff applies to goods Lesotho does not export to the US, so there are no stakeholders lobbying for a change. The timeframe until resolution is very shortâ€”approximately one month. Changes to the Harmonized Tariff Schedule are typically made via official proclamations, a process that is unlikely to be initiated and completed for such a low-priority issue in this window. The lack of any new information from my research assistant reinforces the assumption that the status quo holds. My probability is not higher than 98% to account for the small but non-zero chance that a fix is included in a miscellaneous technical corrections package that has been in the works for some time and happens to be published before the resolution date. My probability is not lower because the multi-decade history of this error, combined with the short timeline and lack of any discernible catalyst for change, makes the continuation of the status quo the overwhelmingly likely outcome. I would lower my forecast upon news of a pending Presidential Proclamation or Federal Register notice regarding technical corrections to the HTS. I would raise it if an official source confirmed no such corrections were planned.

prompt:

This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if the duty provided in the applicable subheading is + 50% for Lesotho at the American government's [harmonized tariff schedule](https://hts.usitc.gov/search?query=lesotho) when accessed by Metaculus on or after June 1, 2025.

Whether the provision is listed as suspended will not affect resolution.


Your research assistant's report says:
No additional information available.

Today is 2025-04-23.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.
